paper_metadata.title: MAIN TEXT
paper_metadata.extraction_summary: The paper discusses the Val30Met mutation in the TTR gene associated with familial amyloid polyneuropathy (FAP) and provides insights into penetrance data among carriers.

patients.demographics: 17 males and 11 females; mean age 36.5 years

individual_records.evidence_sentence: We have classified the asymptomatic patients (or asymptomatic carriers) as those patients diagnosed with ATTRv by means of genetic screening, but that do not present ATTRv symptoms yet.

individual_records.phenotype_details: mild sensory, motor, and autonomic neuropathy
individual_records.evidence_sentence: Twenty-five of them were considered early onset (< 50 years old) and three were considered late-onset (> 50 years old).

individual_records.phenotype_details: severe sensory, motor, and autonomic involvement
individual_records.evidence_sentence: FAP 2 = assistance with ambulation required; mostly moderate impairment progression to the lower limbs, upper limbs, and trunk.

functional_data.summary: The Val30Met mutation leads to the production of dysfunctional TTR with a high thermodynamic instability compared to the wild-type protein.

variants.segregation_data: The Val30Met mutation segregates with disease in families.
variants.evidence_level: Strong evidence based on clinical presentation and genetic confirmation.
variants.additional_notes: The study highlights the need for new biomarkers to identify patients in earlier disease phases.
key_quotes: The Val30Met (V30 M) variant is the most common mutation affecting a large population of people worldwide.
In all patients, the diagnosis was confirmed by histopathology of biopsied material, clinical criteria and genetic sequencing of the TTR gene being all patients V30 M.

extraction_metadata.notes: The extraction was straightforward as the paper focused on the TTR gene and provided clear data.
